summary: This is an internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) discussing a New York Times article about JPMorgan Chase's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. The email asks if they have received information from JPMC regarding why they ended their relationship with Epstein in 2013 and notes the article's claim that executives overruled compliance efforts to remove him as a client in 2008-2009.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the internal email and the NYT article, discussing JPMorgan Chase's decision to keep him as a client despite his prior conviction and internal warnings.

connections.description: Epstein was a client of JPMorgan Chase; the bank kept him as a client despite internal warnings and his prior conviction, ending the relationship in 2013.

events.title: JPMorgan internal debate on Epstein
events.description: Executives at JPMorgan Chase reportedly overruled compliance efforts to remove Jeffrey Epstein as a client during this period.

events.title: JPMorgan ends relationship with Epstein
events.description: JPMorgan Chase terminated its banking relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: NYT publishes article on JPMorgan-Epstein relationship
events.description: The New York Times published an article detailing JPMorgan Chase's continued relationship with Jeffrey Epstein despite his prior conviction and internal warnings.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase kept Jeffrey Epstein as a client despite internal warnings and his prior criminal conviction.
Executives at JPMorgan Chase reportedly overruled compliance efforts to remove Epstein as a client around 2008-2009.
JPMorgan Chase ended its banking relationship with Epstein in 2013.
The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively seeking information from JPMorgan Chase about the termination of the relationship in August 2019.
A New York Times article published on August 8, 2019, was the catalyst for the internal email inquiry.
